meta-content.meta-content:
I am pleased to announce that, along with Craig Walls and my long-time friend and co-worker Gordon Dickens, I am writing a book in Spring Roo for Manning Publications.

I cooked up the idea after interviewing Ben Alex in November. Since Gordon and I are both Spring consultants and trainers and cover a lot of Spring-based technology, we felt that we were poised to jump on the book, as Roo is proving wildly popular and we already had the background to start quickly.  And anyway, I think Manning owes Gordon something as he owns and technically reviews just about every MEAP and a large number of books (just kidding).

We all thank Manning for giving us this opportunity. 

Spring Roo in Action is going to cover all aspects of this tool, including basic functionality, JPA and MVC features, Roo and AspectJ ITDs, add-ons, and a lot more. I am currently wrapping up chapter one, and a MEAP will be coming within a few months. 

This is a big commitment, and so I am going to start some occasional blogging on topics of interest around Roo, and monitoring the book forums and Spring forums, etc. I am looking forward to contributing, and Gordon and I are thrilled that Craig showed interest in participating as well.  He has already been extremely helpful to us in getting started.

More news soon.

BarCamp Philly was held today in downtown, sunny Philadelphia, at the University of the Arts. The registration fee was ridiculously low, and the speaker roster really shaped up quickly to become a who's who of technical speakers both from inside and outside of our area.

Jeremy Grelle has just informed me that the Roo Flex add-on is working against Roo 1.1.0 in snapshot form.  This is great news for me personally, as I'm writing a chapter on RIAs with Roo right now!  This short article is a crib sheet on how to get it working quickly.

h2. What is Spring Roo?Spring Roo is a development tool for building rapid applications with the Spring Framework. It uses a command-line shell, annotations, and the AspectJ compiler to remove boilerplate code from your business application logic, and can automate configuration of many enterprise resources such as JPA, Spring MVC, Web Flow, Email, JMS, NoSQL databases, text searching, JSF, GWT, and much more.h2. Why should I care?Because although many rapid application development frameworks are gaining ground, most of the are based on dynamic languages. Many enterprises are reluctant to move to a dynamically typed language such as Groovy or Ruby and to switch to a mostly convention-driven development framework, as it takes quite a lot of effort to switch their developers to such a platform.h2. How does Roo work?Roo developers write code in Java, using the highly productive Spring Framework. All of the code written in a Roo application is 100% Java, and can be integrated with any Spring or Java API. Further, Roo is not a runtime framework; it mostly gets boilerplate and setup out of your way and automates the mechanical work of managing views, menus, features such as setters and getters, equals() and toString() methods, and the like.A Roo developer can use the Roo shell to create a new object.
h2. Silly Weasel Roo Add-ons ForgeI am maintaining a wiki for this add-ons forge. Please view all content there...
Hello, viewers. I've just received word that I'll be speaking at SpringOne/2GX this year. No link yet but I'm working on that. I'll be down there all week, so I hope to see you there.

Let's say you love the productivity of Roo up to a point, but that point happens to be the web. Unfortunately, the default Spring MVC patterns installed in a Roo web app are pretty heavyweight - adding localization, tiles, tags, jspx, etc...

If you ever set up and then backed-out a Roo configuration for the web, and then did the wrong thing and found it regenerated the default web site scaffold, you may have sighed under your breath that you just wish Roo didn't do that.

Well, you have an option. I'd say it's rather voodoo, but if you want to get prototyping in some web-based applications and just make a simple Spring MVC front-end, but don't want to get Roo involved in anything above, say, the service tier, here's what you can do:

* Make a custom Roo installation directory
* Expand Roo
* remove the bundles for web, webmvc, web-json, gwt, jsf, selenium (and maybe one or two more I can't remember)
* remove the cache directory from Roo (it copies the deployed add-ons into this cache as part of the Equinox OSGi container).
* start up Roo, and see if it sends any OSGi errors your way. If it does, you've forgotten to remove a bundle. Try again - shut down the shell, follow the removal step, clear the cache directory, and  restart.

There you are. Now, you can enjoy using Roo for the Aspect-J ITDs, and to make modeling data easier, but if you are simply using Spring MVC for a RESTful front-end, now Roo doesn't get in your way anymore.

You can always link your roo.sh shell script for this version of roo to something like /usr/bin/roo-lite.

Happy Roo'ing.

Ken

update-log-entry.description:
On OS X, there is no sha256sum utility, but a more generic one, shasum . This is good, but it takes standard input or a file, each of which will end up appending a newline on OS X.

 Here was the workaround I found (thank you to this Stack Overflow thread ).

 
echo -n passwd|shasum -a256

Hi Ken,Nice post! Can Roo handle (out of the box) an Accept header like --Accept: application/xml;q=1.0, application/json;q=0.6In which client makes it clear that it can accept XML and JSON media-types, however it prefers XML over JSON (indicating by its q parameter value).

Ok, the main reason you have a problem is that you need to install GPG (a pretty-good-privacy system).  You then have to sign a key and make sure you remember the key signing password.During the build, it will ask you to provide that signing key.  The reason is that the build is signed so it can be loaded to the maven repositories.  I don't know why they make us do this in a development build, but once you do it once, it is set for that point forward.Let me know if this helps.

Doug,Sure, I do.  There is only one dependency in the project that you have to build separately, and that's wrapping.  Do a 'cd' to the ./mapping directory under the roo-git source tree, and do a mvn install there.  Then, cd back to the main directory and do a mvn install.  If you look in the wrapping directory, you'll see a readme.txt that mentions that you have to do this.Sorry for not including it.Ken

Now from github: https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-rooIt's very easy, just follow the readme.txt instructions.Actually it's a simple mvn clean install (with maven 3 and Java 6 and a MAVEN_OPTS for mempry), but you need to configure gpg before (very easy in Mac, not to difficult in windows and not too bad in Ubuntu) But you tell us in a previous POST how to avoid the signature step ;)Then a ln -s in *NIX:sudo ln -s $ROO_HOME/bootstrap/roo-dev /usr/bin/roo-devsudo chmod +x /usr/bin/roo-devIn windows, add roo-dev to the path.You can even debug Roo importing the projects in Eclipse. Existing in workspace if you previously run mvn install eclipse:clean eclipse:eclipse

Thanks for your comments. The challenge with a book that has to address this kind of sweep is that we can't cover everything. I agree, if you're going cloud AND you want to go Google App Engine, there is the whole Data Nucleus thing. Because we had trouble with the GWT plugin (and we're not GWT experts) we pulled back on that, and that also led to a conscious decision to kind of hold off on any deep discussion around Google App Engine since it was a bit of a rabbit hole.

I'm no expert but the way the messaging is used here smells more like an anti-pattern.Why? Because you need to look into the code of the service class too see how and what it returns!Use this feature eg. for decoupled events between controllers...

Tom,If it's just a simple process with an async result, you can certainly just implement it inline (like using a $http.get() directly from a controller function and providing the results asynchronously directly to the $scope - instant data binding).But I was showing the results of a service object - something shared and injected to one or more controllers. And something where a few areas may be interested in the result.  If we passed the scope (I am feeling this it the biggest code smell) it would narrow-cast back to the object and below that was formed in that scope or children. If we instead didn't pass a scope to communicate with and send our messages via $rootScope instead, we get an event bus, where maybe more than one thing may be interested in the message.For my own understanding I need to do more research. Off the top of your head, what do you think would a better alternative approach be that could a) handle it asynchronously and b) be re-used in several controllers? Maybe returning a future object from the service?Thanks for opening up a discussion on this.Ken

I am so sorry - been so busy I didn't even notice the message coming in.Actually the mvn install command would be for the project made in Roo, you would download an install of Roo (not the source) and then unzip it. You'd then remove the bundles from the Roo install.The Roo shell would then not have anything that would try to 'own' the war project, so you should be able to develop in peace.Ken

Nice ramblings lol :) This Roo thing seems a wee bit complex tho... like just another framework to learn. I've been looking around at all the different RADs out there... I'm really looking for a RAD that makes development super simple for me because I'm constantly creating web apps for clients. I looked at Spring Boot (it was difficult) and Spring Roo (it was dificult too). The traditional choice is Maven but Ima buck the system kind of guy. I've been fiddling around with one I found called Jigy Generator... it's super simple. It generates your Spring project with everything completely configured for you without having to learn anything additional. It also reverse engineers your database to create all your DAO's, domain objects and validators for you. Plus you have certain things that just work out of the box like login, authentication, file upload etc. Have you tried this one? I got it from getjigy.com

No, I haven't seen that.  The Roo add-ons particularly are tough to write as you're writing code in relatively undocumented APIs, but the base features such as controllers and ORM code are relatively easy to work with.

I do. There is only one dependency in the project that you have to build separately, and that's wrapping. Do a 'cd' to the ./mapping directory under the roo-git source tree, and do a mvn install there. Then, cd back to the main directory and do a mvn install. If you look in the wrapping directory, you'll see a readme.txt that mentions that you have to do this.

picture-gallery.title: Black and White Portfolio
picture-gallery.description: A collection of my best Black and White work.  Much of the early work is done with medium format and 35mm film cameras, but lately I am shooting digital as well.

picture-gallery.title: Color Portfolio
picture-gallery.description: Some of my favorite and representative color pictures.

picture-gallery.title: Fuji X100S - Travels Gallery
picture-gallery.description: I couldn't stand it anymore. The X100 being stolen last year killed my photography-fu. I picked up the successor, Fujifilm's even better X100s. Here are a few pictures from recent travels to Charlotte, NC and Denver/Boulder, CO. more will be posted.

picture-gallery.title: iPhone 4 Photo Gallery
picture-gallery.description: What the hell?  It's a phone, AND a camera?  Like a desert topping and a floor wax?  Yes, I'm an Apple fanboy.  But the 3G and the 2G cameras, well, s-u-c-k-e-d.But this time, they really are on to something.  I am SO impressed with how it renders images that I don't take any point-and-shoot cameras with me anymore.  Nope.  Don't need 'em.  Either this or this + the DSLR!

picture-gallery.title: Longwood Gardens
picture-gallery.description: This is a photo gallery from a recent Longwood Gardens trip.  I used the EOS 5D and the G10 as a duo.  It was a very rainy day, so most of my shots were done between the drops.

picture-gallery.title: Portfolio (the quick view)
picture-gallery.description: Here are some of my favorites, collected over the years. If you want to just get a quick feel for my photography style, this'd do it.

picture-gallery.title: Ridley Creek with G10
picture-gallery.description: After getting the G10 for a replacement point-and-shoot and general carry everywhere camera, I took it to Ridley for 15 minutes during an errand to see what it can do in good light.

picture-gallery.title: Ridley Creek with M8 and CV 75mm f/2.5
picture-gallery.description: Took the girls to the park today on a generally foggy and cloudy day.  Apparently the painters were out in force at the horse park, and the colors just popped with saturation. Hope you enjoy it.

picture-gallery.title: Rimple Takes Manhattan
picture-gallery.description: My trip to Manhattan, toting along the Canon G10 (and maybe an iPhone pic or two)

picture-gallery.title: San Francisco
picture-gallery.description: A trip in December 2013 to San Francisco for an Android conference.... Took my Note 3 and Sony RX100 with me... Here are a few pictures.

picture-gallery.title: Sony RX-100 Mini-powerhouse samples
picture-gallery.description: Here are my initial better photos with the RX-100, Sony's best point and shoot camera ever. A larger sensor mated with a fast platform, this thing does quite a lot. I bought it to replace my Fuji X-100 which was stolen after our last conference. Sad to say, I miss the Fuji with the optical viewfinder and larger sensor, but this is a great alternative for 1/2 the price.

picture-gallery.title: The Fuji X-100 camera
picture-gallery.description: An amazing camera - a rangefinder styling, with excellent high-ISO capabilities and a lovely through-the-viewfinder heads up display. Takes fantastic pictures. Here are a few of my favorites.Sadly, mine was stolen at a tech conference. I miss it dearly.

picture-gallery.title: Tyler Arboretum
picture-gallery.description: Pictures taken early October, at the beginning of the turn of the season.  I focused on close-up pictures rather than landscapes, trying to extract the colors and textures of fall flowers.
